response.answer_text: He is described as a Moor, originally a term for a Muslim from what is now roughly Morocco, Spain, Sicily or Malta. By Shakespeare’s time it was a term applied to all Arabs and even European Muslims. The descriptions of him in Shakespeare’s text, such as they are, would lead one to conclude that he was certainly not a ‘white’ Caucasian man. It can make for some uncomfortable viewing. Olivier, blacked up like a minstrel playing the part, looks, to be polite, dated.

Sub-Saharan Africans were known in London at the time and if Shakespeare wanted to he could have written a play about them. He didn’t; the Moors were the North African invaders of Spain, Berber and Arab. Swarthiness yes; as with the population of London our “black” people could exist amongst the Moors but the Moors were North Africa Muslim. If you think all non-Europeans are “black” then Othello was “black”; otherwise they were dark compared to the average Brit but not West Africans.
